sen.j: 矢野 玄道（やの はるみち、1823年12月18日（文政6年11月17日 (旧暦)） - 1887年5月19日）は、伊予国喜多郡阿蔵村有松（現、愛媛県大洲市）の国学者・神道学者である。
sen.e: Harumichi YANO, born on December 18, 1823, in Arimatsu, Azo Village, Kita County, Iyo Province (present-day Osu City, Ehime Prefecture), is a scholar of Japanese classical culture and theologian.
Harumichi YANO, born on December 18, 1823, in Arimatsu, Azo Village, Kita County, Iyo Province (present-day Osu City, Ehime Prefecture), was a scholar of Japanese classical culture and a theologian.
Harumichi YANO, born on December 18, 1823, in Arimatsu, Azo Village, Kita County, Iyo Province (present-day Osu City, Ehime Prefecture), was a scholar of Japanese classical culture and a theologian.

sen.j: 幼名は茂太郎、号は天放散人、子清、神臣、谷倶久、後楽閑人、扶桑眞人倚松、谷蟆、梅屋。
sen.e: He was called Shigetaro in his childhood and also called 'Tenhosanjin', 'shisei', 'shinshin', 'yaguhisa', 'korakukanjin','fusoshinjinisho', ' yaba' and 'umeya'.
sen.cmt: 天放散人、子清、神臣、谷倶久、後楽閑人、扶桑眞人倚松、谷蟆、梅屋の確かな日本語読みが調べられませんでしたので、「梅屋」以外は音読みにしています。
sen.e: He was called Shigetaro in his childhood and also called 'Tenhosanjin', 'shisei', 'shinshin', 'yaguhisa', 'korakukanjin', 'fusoshinjinisho', ' yaba' and 'umeya'.
He was called Shigetaro in his childhood and also called 'Tenhosanjin', 'shisei', 'shinshin', 'yaguhisa', 'korakukanjin', 'fusoshinjinisho', 'yaba' and 'umeya'.
sen.cmt: yabaの前のスペースを除去しました。

sen.j: 本姓は平氏（佐奈田余一義忠次男中山次郎盛実末）。
sen.e: The original surname is 'Heishi'.
sen.cmt: 中山次郎盛実末の意味が不確かなため、カッコ内を訳出していません。
sen.e: His original surname was 'Heishi'.
His original surname was 'Heishi'.

sen.j: 経歴
sen.e: Career
Career
Career

sen.j: 略年譜
sen.e: Brief Chronological Table
Brief Chronological Table
Brief Chronological Table

sen.j: 文政6年（1823年） 大洲藩矢野仙左衛門道正の子として、伊予国喜多郡に生まれる。
sen.e: He was born in Kita Country, Iyo Province as a son of Senzaemondosei YANO, a statesman of the Osu clan.
sen.cmt: 道正の確かな読みが不確かなため、音読み「どうせい」としました
sen.e: He was born in Kita Country, Iyo Province as a son of Senzaemondosei YANO, a statesman of the Osu clan.
He was born in Kita Country, Iyo Province as a son of Senzaemondosei YANO, a statesman of the Osu clan.

sen.j: 文政8年(1825年) 三・四歳の頃、祖母の懐中に在りて千字文の類を読誦す。
sen.e: In 1825, at around age of three, he read some books of about 1000 words in his mother's arms.
In 1825, at around the age of three, he read some books of around 1,000 words while in his mother's arms.
In 1825, at around three years of age, he read some books of around 1,000 words while in his grand mother's arms.
sen.cmt: 一部、翻訳を変更しました。

sen.j: 文政10年(1827年) 父・道正に就き書道を始める。
sen.e: In 1827, his father Dosei gave him calligraphy lessons.
In 1827, his father Dosei gave him calligraphy lessons.
In 1827, his father Dosei gave him calligraphy lessons.

sen.j: 天保4年（1833年） 平田篤胤に入門した父の勧めで国学を志す。
sen.e: In 1833, he started studying Japanese classical culture with recommendation from his father who became a disciple of Atsutane HIRATA.
In 1833, he started studying Japanese classical culture as recommended by his father who became a disciple of Atsutane HIRATA.
In 1833, he started studying Japanese classical culture as recommended by his father who became a disciple of Atsutane HIRATA.

sen.j: 天保11年(1840年) 松山の日下伯巌の塾(明教館)に入門。
sen.e: In 1840, he became a disciple of Hakugan KUSAKA (a professor of Meikyokan).
In 1840, he became a disciple of Hakugan KUSAKA (a professor of Meikyokan).
In 1840, he became a disciple of Hakugan KUSAKA (a professor of Meikyokan).

sen.j: 天保12年(1841年) 玄道19歳の折、名を敬逵(たかみち)と称し扶桑真人倚松と号す。
sen.e: In 1841, at the age of 19, he changed his name to 'Takamichi' and was called 'fusoshinjinisho'.
In 1841, at the age of 19, he changed his name to 'Takamichi' and was called 'fusoshinjinisho'.
In 1841, at the age of 19, he changed his name to 'Takamichi' and was called 'fusoshinjinisho'.

sen.j: 弘化元年(1844年) 二月下旬周防国から長門国を経由して、豊後国の宇佐八幡宮や筑前国の筥崎宮、太宰府天満宮などを参拝する。
sen.e: In the end of February, 1844, he set out on a journey to Kyushu to visit Usahachimangu-Shrine in Bungo Province, Hakozakigu-Shrine and Dazaifu tenmangu Shrine in Chikuzen Province via Nagato Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一翻訳の例外処理
sen.e: At the end of February, 1844, he set out on a journey to Kyushu to visit the Usahachimangu-Shrine in Bungo Province, the Hakozakigu-Shrine and the Dazaifu tenmangu Shrine in Chikuzen Province via Nagato Province.

At the end of February, 1844, he set out on a journey to Kyushu to visit the Usahachimangu-Shrine in Bungo Province, the Hakozakigu-Shrine and the Dazaifu tenmangu Shrine in Chikuzen Province via Nagato Province.

sen.j: その後、日向国の神代古蹟を探訪後、薩摩国の霧島神宮を参詣のち霧島山に登る。
sen.e: After visiting Shindai ruins in Hyuga Province, he visited Kirishima-jingu Shrine in Satsuma Province and then, he climbed Mt. Kirishima-yama.
sen.cmt: 一原文一翻訳の例外処理
sen.e: After visiting the Shindai ruins in Hyuga Province, he visited the Kirishima-jingu Shrine in Satsuma Province and then, he climbed Mt. Kirishima-yama.
After visiting the Shindai ruins in Hyuga Province, he visited the Kirishima-jingu Shrine in Satsuma Province and then, he climbed Mt. Kirishima-yama.

sen.j: 以後肥後国を経て熊本の阿蘇山に登り帰来して見聞記を録す。
sen.e: After that, he climbed Mt. Aso in Kumamoto Province via Higo Province and when he came back, he recorded chronicle of his experience.
After that, he climbed Mt. Aso in Kumamoto Province via Higo Province and when he came back, he recorded a chronicle of his experience.
After that, he climbed Mt. Aso in Kumamoto Province via Higo Province and when he came back, he recorded a chronicle of his experience.

sen.j: 弘化2年（1845年） 京都に上洛し、新宮涼庭の順正書院に入塾。
sen.e: In 1845, he went to Kyoto and entered the school, 'Junsei shoin' run by Ryotei SHINGU.
In 1845, he went to Kyoto and entered the school, 'Junsei shoin' run by Ryotei SHINGU.
In 1845, he went to Kyoto and entered the school, 'Junsei shoin' run by Ryotei SHINGU.

sen.j: 伴信友や八田知紀を訪ねて交流す。
sen.e: He visited Nobutomo BAN and Tomonori Hatta, cultivating their friendship.
He visited Nobutomo BAN and Tomonori Hatta, cultivating their friendship.
He visited Nobutomo BAN and Tomonori Hatta, cultivating their friendship.

sen.j: 弘化4年(1847年) 正月19日正式に平田家に入門する。
sen.e: On January 19, 1847, he formally entered the Hirata school.
On January 19, 1847, he formally entered the Hirata school.
On March 5, 1847, he formally entered the Hirata school.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: また24日には昌平坂学問所に入塾する。
sen.e: Then, on January 24, he entered 'Shoheizaka gakumonsho' (prestigious school).
Then, on January 24th, he entered 'Shoheizaka gakumonsho' (prestigious school).
Then, on March 10, he entered 'Shoheizaka gakumonsho' (prestigious school).
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: 嘉永5年（1852年） 正月鳩居堂に寓居す。
sen.e: On January 1, 1852, he temporally lived in Kyuhodo.
On January 1, 1852, he temporally lived in Kyuhodo.
On January 21, 1852, he temporally lived in Kyukyodo.

sen.j: 皇学所設置の建白書を提出す。
sen.e: He presented his plan to set up schools providing higher level education centering on Shinto and Japanese classical culture to the government.
He presented his plan to set up schools providing higher level education centering on Shinto and Japanese classical culture to the government.
He presented his plan to set up schools providing higher level education centering on Shinto and Japanese classical culture to the government.

sen.j: 安政2年（1855年） ライフワークの一つでもある『皇典翼』の執筆を開始。
sen.e: In 1855, he started writing "Kotenyoku" whichi was one of his lifework.
In 1855, he started writing "Kotenyoku" which was one of his life's works.
In 1855, he started writing "Kotenyoku" which was one of his life's works.

sen.j: 慶応3年（1867年） 建白書が朝廷で議論され、設置の方向で話が進む。
sen.e: In 1867, his plan was discussed in the Imperial Court and they came to an agreement on setting up schools.
In 1867, his plan was discussed in the Imperial Court and they came to an agreement on setting up schools.
In 1867, his plan was discussed in the Imperial Court and they came to an agreement on setting up schools.

sen.j: 明治3年（1870年） 2月、東京に召され、大学中博士となり従六位に叙せられる。
sen.e: In February 1870, he was called in Tokyo and received the title of Doctor of Philosophy and the honor of Jurokui (Junior Sixth Rank).
In February 1870, he was called to Tokyo and received the title of Doctor of Philosophy and the honor of Jurokui (Junior Sixth Rank).
In March 1870, he was called to Tokyo and received the title of Doctor of Philosophy and the honor of Jurokui (Junior Sixth Rank).
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: 明治10年（1877年） 玄道55歳の五月より病みて久しく回復しなかった
sen.e: In 1877, at the age of 55, he had been sick for a while since May.
sen.cmt: 一原文一翻訳の例外処理
sen.e: In 1877, at the age of 55, he had been sick for some time since May.
In 1877, at the age of 55, he had been sick for some time since May.

sen.j: その間2月から3月にかけて、『魂神要論』及び『本教学柱』を書き上げる。
sen.e: During that time from February to March, he completed writing "kishinyoron" and "Honkyogakuchu".
sen.cmt: 一原文一翻訳の例外処理
sen.e: During the time from February to March, he completed writing "kishinyoron" and "Honkyogakuchu".
During the time from February to March, he completed writing "Kishinyoron" and "Honkyogakuchu."
sen.cmt: kishinyoronをKishinyoronに変更しました。ピリオドを" "内に移動させました。

sen.j: 弟・直道、親友・常磐井精戈と上京。
sen.e: He went to Kyoto with his brother, Naomichi and his close friend, Seika TOKIWAI.
He went to Kyoto with his brother, Naomichi and his close friend, Seika TOKIWAI.
He went to Kyoto with his brother, Naomichi and his close friend, Seika TOKIWAI.

sen.j: 12月15日 太政官修史館御用掛を任じられる。
sen.e: On December 15, he was appointed as 'Dajyokanshushikan goyogakari' (a high ranking government employee who worked on compiling Japanese history).
On December 15th, he was appointed as 'Dajyokanshushikan goyogakari' (a high ranking government employee who worked on compiling Japanese history).
On December 15th, he was appointed as 'Dajyokanshushikan goyogakari' (a high ranking government employee who worked on compiling Japanese history).

sen.j: 明治15年(1882年) 皇典講究所の初代文学部長になる。
sen.e: In 1882, he became the first head of faculty of literature in Koten kokyusho (the Institution for Shinto Study).
In 1882, he became the first head of faculty of literature at the Koten kokyusho (the Institution for the study of Shinto).
In 1882, he became the first head of faculty of literature at the Koten kokyusho (the Institution for the study of Shinto).

sen.j: 明治16年(1883年 1月19日御系譜勤務となる。
sen.e: On January 19, 1883, he was transferred to another position, 'gokeifu'.(genealogy of the Imperial family)
On January 19, 1883, he was transferred to another position, 'gokeifu' (genealogy of the Imperial family).
On January 19, 1883, he was transferred to another position, 'gokeifu' (genealogy of the Imperial family).

sen.j: 『続皇国神仙記』完成す。
sen.e: He finished writing a book. "zoku kokoku shinsenki".
He finished writing a book titled "zoku kokoku shinsenki".
He finished writing a book titled "zoku kokoku shinsenki".

sen.j: 明治19年（1886年） 帰郷し、母親の介護に当たるが、12月14日に母親が亡くなる。
sen.e: In 1886, he returned to his hometown and took care of his mother, but on December 14, she died.
In 1886, he returned to his hometown and took care of his mother, however on December 14th, she died.
In 1886, he returned to his hometown and took care of his mother, however on December 14th, she died.

sen.j: 人格
sen.e: Personality
Personality
Personality

sen.j: 玄道は青年時に学んだ老荘思想の影響により、名誉や高い地位を求めなかった。
sen.e: He was profoundly influenced by Taoism which he learned in his younger days, so he did not seek for honor or high ranking positions.
sen.cmt: 一原文一翻訳の例外処理
sen.e: He was profoundly influenced by Taoism which he learned in his younger days, so he did not seek honor or high ranking positions.
He was profoundly influenced by Taoism which he learned in his younger days, so he did not seek honor or high ranking positions.

sen.j: また、妻を娶る事なく一生独身で通し、他の事に一切構わず、一心不乱に国学の研鑽に励み、一生を国学の著書の執筆に捧げた。
sen.e: Moreover, he was a single all his life without caring earthly affairs and devoted whole his life into writing books of the study of Japanese classical culture, making maximum effort to learn it more with his heart and soul.
sen.cmt: 一原文一翻訳の例外処理
sen.e: Moreover, he was single all his life without caring for earthly affairs he devoted his whole life to writing books on the study of Japanese classical culture, making maximum effort to learn it more with his heart and soul.

Moreover, he was single all his life without caring for earthly affairs he devoted his whole life to writing books on the study of Japanese classical culture, making maximum effort to learn it more with his heart and soul.

sen.j: 読書をすると、必ず大事な所や学者の考えを書き残し、記憶に留める事を忘れなかった。
sen.e: Whenever he read books, he never failed to take notes about important things or thoughts of scholars and try to memorize these things.
Whenever he read books, he never failed to take notes about important things or thoughts of scholars and try to memorize these things.
Whenever he read books, he never failed to take notes about important things or thoughts of scholars and try to memorize these things.

sen.j: まさに博覧強記で、玄道の筆写した書物の数は、約700巻にも及んでいる。
sen.e: He read tremendous amount of books of various regions and categories and the numbers of books he copied reached about 700 volumes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一翻訳の例外処理
sen.e: He read tremendous amounts of books on various regions and categories and the numbers of books he copied reached about 700 volumes.
He read tremendous amounts of books on various regions and categories and the numbers of books he copied reached about 700 volumes.

sen.j: 大洲市立図書館にある矢野文庫には、子孫が寄贈した玄道蒐集の本や論考の大半が保存されている。
sen.e: Yano bunko placed in the public library of Osu City preserves most of the collections of his books and theses which his descendants presented.
sen.cmt: 一原文一翻訳の例外処理
sen.e: Yano bunko placed in the public library of Osu City preserves most of the collections of his books and theses which his descendants presented.
Yano bunko placed in the public library of Osu City preserves most of the collections of his books and theses which his descendants presented.
